Holanda admet la mort de 70 civils a l'Iraq en un atac amb avions seus
Els fets van ocórrer l'any 2015 però l'executiu ho havia ocultat al Parlament

04 Nov 2019, 18:57

El ministeri holandès de Defensa ha reconegut aquest dilluns que un dels seus avions F-16 va causar la mort de desenes de civils el 3 de juny del 2015 a la localitat de Hawija, a la província de Kirkuk, al nord de l'Iraq, durant el bombardeig d'un recinte on l'Estat Islàmic suposadament fabricava bombes. Entre les víctimes, hi havia diversos infants.
És la primera vegada que el govern holandès reconeix aquests fets. L'actual ministra de Defensa, Ank Bijleveld, ha enviat una carta al Parlament aquest dilluns en què admet que, efectivament, el bombardeig va tenir unes conseqüències fatals. En canvi, la seva predecessora, Jeanine Hennis, ho havia negat: aleshores va assegurar a la cambra legislativa que cap civil havia mort durant l'atac.
"Abans de l'atac no hi havia indicis que hi haguessin civils prop de l'objectiu. Les cases més properes estaven fora de l'àrea de danys que es va proporcionar al començament. Després de l'atac, es van produir diverses explosions secundàries, cosa que va fer que l'àrea afectada fos més gran", ha argumentat la ministra, que també ha detallat que "unes 70 persones van morir en l'atac, tant combatents de l'Estat Islàmic com civils".
La titular de Defensa ha fet pública aquesta informació després que una investigació periodística posés en evidència fa dues setmanes que les forces holandeses havien provocat fins a 70 morts, tots civils, a la localitat de Hawija. Quan aquesta informació es va publicar, el govern holandès va declinar corroborar si aquestes dades eren certes o no, o si estava al corrent d'aquest incident.
La ministra de Defensa també ha reconegut aquest dilluns que el 21 de setembre del 2015 les forces holandeses van dur a terme un altre bombardeig que va afectar una casa on vivien civils, però en aquest cas a la ciutat iraquiana de Mossul. Almenys quatre persones van morir.
Entre l'octubre del 2014 i el desembre del 2018, les tropes holandeses van contribuir amb diversos avions F-16 a les operacions militars que la coalició internacional va dur a terme contra el grup terrorista Estat Islàmic a l'Iraq i Síria. "La mort de civils als bombardejos és un exemple commovedor dels riscos associats a la participació en la lluita contra un enemic com l'Estat Islàmic. Això és encara més amarg quan les nostres accions tenien com a objectiu evitar al màxim els danys col·laterals i especialment les baixes civils", ha justificat la ministra.
text:
The Netherlands admits the death of 70 civilians in Iraq in an attack with their aircraft
The events took place in 2015 but the executive had hidden it in Parliament

04 Nov 2019, 18:57

The Dutch Ministry of Defense has acknowledged Monday that one of its F-16 aircraft caused the deaths of dozens of civilians on June 3, 2015 in the town of Hawija, in the province of Kirkuk, in northern Iraq, during the bombing of a site where the Islamic State allegedly manufactured bombs. Among the victims, there were several children.
It is the first time that the Dutch government recognizes these facts. Defense Minister Ank Bijleveld has sent a letter to Parliament on Monday that he admits that the bombing was indeed fatal. Instead, his predecessor, Jeanine Hennis, had denied it: then he asserted in the legislative chamber that no civilian had died during the attack.
"Before the attack there were no indications that there were civilians near the target. The nearest houses were outside the area of damage that was provided at the beginning. After the attack, there were several explosions secondary, which made the affected area bigger ", the minister said, which also detailed that" about 70 people died in the attack, both combatants of the Islamic State and civilians. "
The head of Defense has issued this information after a journalistic investigation showed two weeks ago that the Dutch forces had caused up to 70 deaths, all civilians, in the town of Hawija. When this information was published, the Dutch government declined to corroborate whether these data were true or not, or if it was aware of this incident.
The Minister of Defense also acknowledged Monday that on September 21, 2015, the Dutch forces carried out another bombardment that affected a house where civilians lived, but in this case in the Iraqi city of Mossul. At least four people died.
Between October 2014 and December 2018, Dutch troops contributed several F-16 aircraft to the military operations that the international coalition carried out against the Islamic State terrorist group in Iraq and Syria. "The death of civilians in the bombing is a moving example of the risks associated with participation in the fight against an enemy like the Islamic State. This is even more bitter when our actions were aimed at avoiding as much as possible the collateral damage and especially civil casualties, "the minister justified.
